questions.text: A male patient presented with a history of fever and joint pain. Following intake of NSAIDs 5 days later developed hyperpigmentation over the nose. What is your Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chikungunya can lead to hyperpigmentation over the nose, called a chick sign. This pigmentation is not related to drugs.

Chikungunya fever, a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, can sometimes lead to a unique skin manifestation known as the "chick sign." This is a type of hyperpigmentation that appears as a dark patch over the nose.

Key points about the "chick sign" in chikungunya:

  • Unrelated to drug intake: Unlike other forms of hyperpigmentation, the "chick sign" is not associated with drug reactions or other underlying diseases.
  • Follow fever and joint pain: It typically appears after the initial phase of fever and joint pain, which are common symptoms of chikungunya.
  • Distinct appearance: The "chick sign" is characterized by a dark, well-defined patch over the nose.

Option A: Melasma is not related to fever or NSAIDS intake. It is commonly seen in females. Risk factors are photo exposure, hormonal imbalance or oc pill intake.

Option B: FDR is a drug reaction. Vesicles or bullae develop over skin or mucosa which leaves hyperpigmentation. It recur over the same site if drug exposure occurs.

Option D: Dengue rash are erythema with a typical appearance of 'islands of white in sea of red'. Petechial rash may develop if platelets counts are low.

Key Takeaway:

Chikungunya fever can cause hyperpigmentation over the nose, known as the "chick sign," which is unrelated to drug intake. This condition typically follows fever and joint pain and is distinct from other forms of hyperpigmentation associated with drug reactions or other diseases.

Reference: Seetharam KA, Sridevi K, Vidyasagar P. Cutaneous Manifestations of Chikungunya. Indian Pediatr 2012; 49:51.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image showing hyperpigmented patches on the face, typically affecting the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip in a symmetrical pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Melasma is a common skin condition characterized by hyperpigmentation (darkening) of the skin in sun-exposed areas, typically the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip. The patches are often brown or gray-brown in color.

Key features of melasma:

  • Symmetrical distribution: The patches are usually symmetrical on both sides of the face.
  • Hormonal factors: Melasma is often associated with hormonal changes, such as those during pregnancy or from oral contraceptive use.
  • Sun exposure: Exposure to sunlight can worsen melasma.

Treatment options for melasma include:

  • Sun protection: Using broad-spectrum sunscreen with a high SPF is essential to prevent further darkening and protect the skin.
  • Topical agents: Hydroquinone, kojic acid, and azelaic acid are commonly used topical agents to lighten the dark patches.
  • Chemical peels: Chemical peels can help improve the appearance of melasma by exfoliating the affected skin.

Option A. Photodermatitis: This refers to an inflammatory skin reaction due to exposure to sunlight or certain chemicals. It typically presents with redness, itching, and sometimes blisters, rather than the symmetric hyperpigmentation seen in melasma.

Option C. Lentigines are small, well-defined spots that appear due to sun exposure, often referred to as age spots.

Option D. Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation occurs after an inflammatory skin condition and is characterized by darkening of the skin in the area of previous injury or irritation.

Key Takeaway:

Melasma is identified by symmetrical hyperpigmented patches on sun-exposed areas of the face, primarily affecting the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip, often linked to hormonal changes and exacerbated by sun exposure.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image showing a blue-gray pigmented lesion on the lower back of an infant.
questions.solution:
Mongolian spots are common birthmarks that appear as blue-gray or slate-colored patches on the skin, often on the lower back or buttocks. They are most prevalent in individuals of Asian, African, or Hispanic descent.

Key characteristics of Mongolian spots:

  • Congenital: They are present at birth.
  • Color: Typically blue-gray or slate-colored.
  • Location: Most commonly found on the lower back or buttocks, but can also appear on other parts of the body.
  • No treatment needed: Mongolian spots are usually harmless and do not require treatment. They often fade over time, especially during childhood.

Incorrect options-

Option A: Nevus of Ota: It is a bluish discoloration along the Ophthalmic & Maxillary divisions of the Trigeminal nerve. It is unilateral.

Option C: Blue Nevus: Usually appears as a small blue or blue-black lesion, often found on the scalp or extremities, rather than the lower back.

Option D: Cafe-au-lait Spot: Light brown macules that can be found on any part of the body, but do not have the blue-gray color characteristic of a Mongolian spot.

Key Takeaway:

Mongolian Spot is a blue-gray or slate-colored macule commonly found on the lower back or buttocks of infants, particularly in individuals of Asian, African, or Hispanic descent, and is a type of congenital dermal melanocytosis.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image showing a blue-gray pigmented lesion on the face, particularly around the eye and forehead.
questions.solution:
Nevus of Ota:

  • Dermal melanocytosis: Characterized by an excess of melanin pigment in the deeper layers of the skin (dermis).
  • Blue-gray pigmentation: Presents as a bluish or grayish discoloration on the face.
  • Facial location: Primarily affects the area around the eye and forehead.
  • Scleral involvement: In some cases, the pigmentation can involve the white part of the eye (sclera).
  • Trigeminal nerve distribution: Follows the distribution of the ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the forehead, eye, and upper cheek.
  • Unilateral: Typically affects one side of the face.

Option A: Melasma: This usually appears as brown or tan patches, commonly on the cheeks and forehead, often related to hormonal changes and sun exposure.

Option C: Blue nevus: This is a benign melanocytic lesion that appears as a blue or blue-black spot, often seen on the scalp or extremities but does not usually involve the periorbital area.

Option D: Café-au-lait spots: These are light brown macules typically associated with neurofibromatosis and do not have the characteristic blue-gray color of a nevus of Ota.

Key Takeaway

Nevus of Ota is identified by blue-gray pigmentation on the face, particularly around the eye and forehead, and is a type of dermal melanocytosis associated with the trigeminal nerve.

choices.text: It is a congenital melanocytic nevus.
It typically presents as a small, flat, hyperpigmented lesion.
It is often associated with underlying muscle or skeletal abnormalities.
It commonly appears in females during adolescence.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Becker's nevus?
questions.solution:
Becker's nevus is a benign skin condition characterized by hyperpigmented patches of skin that are often associated with increased hair growth (hypertrichosis).

Key features of Becker's nevus:

  • Hyperpigmentation: The affected skin is darker than the surrounding skin.
  • Hypertrichosis: There is often increased hair growth within the pigmented area.
  • Location: Becker's nevus can appear anywhere on the body, but they are most commonly found on the upper body and arms.
  • Muscle or connective tissue abnormalities: In some cases, Becker's nevi may be associated with underlying muscle or connective tissue abnormalities.

Option A. It is a congenital melanocytic nevus.

  • Becker's nevus is usually acquired rather than congenital.

Option B. It typically presents as a small, flat, hyperpigmented lesion.

  • Becker's nevus usually appears as a larger, irregularly shaped, hyperpigmented patch, often with coarse hair.

Option C. It is often associated with underlying muscle or skeletal abnormalities.

  • Becker's nevus can be associated with abnormalities such as hypoplasia of the underlying muscle.

Option D. It commonly appears in females during adolescence.

  • Becker's nevus is more commonly seen in males and typically develops during puberty.

Key takeaway:

Becker's nevus is characterized by hyperpigmented skin, often with increased hair growth (hypertrichosis), and can appear anywhere on the body but is most commonly found on the upper body and arms. It is thought to be related to an increase in melanocyte activity.

questions.text: Hypopigmented lesion are present in:
questions.solution:
Nevus anemicus is a benign skin condition characterized by hypopigmented (pale) macules or patches. It occurs due to localized vasoconstriction, meaning that the blood vessels in the affected area narrow, reducing blood flow to the skin. This often results in a pale or white spot on the skin.

Key features of nevus anemicus:

  • Hypopigmentation: The affected area appears pale or white compared to the surrounding skin.
  • Vasoconstriction: Caused by localized hypersensitivity to catecholamines, a group of hormones that regulate blood pressure and heart rate.
  • Stability: Nevus anemicus is typically stable and does not change in size or appearance over time.

Option A. Nevus of Ota: This is a dermal melanocytic nevus characterized by blue-gray pigmentation, primarily affecting the face and often associated with increased pigmentation, not hypopigmentation.

Option B. Nevus of Ito: Similar to the nevus of Ota, this nevus presents with blue-gray pigmentation but is located more on the shoulder or upper back region, again not hypopigmented.

Option D. Becker nevus: This is typically characterized by hyperpigmented patches that may also have increased hair growth (hypertrichosis) but does not present as hypopigmented lesions.

Key Takeaway

Nevus anemicus is characterized by hypopigmented macules or patches due to localized vasoconstriction, resulting in reduced blood flow and pale spots on the skin.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image showing a person with a patch of depigmented skin and a white forelock of hair since birth
questions.solution:
Piebaldism is a genetic condition characterized by the absence of melanin, a pigment that gives skin, hair, and eyes their color. This lack of melanin results in white patches of skin and hair.

Key features of piebaldism:

  • White forelock: The most distinctive feature is a tuft of white hair that is present at birth.
  • Hypopigmented patches: Other white patches may appear on the skin, often in a symmetrical pattern.
  • Genetic inheritance: Piebaldism is an autosomal dominant condition, meaning that a person only needs one copy of the affected gene to develop the condition.
  • Prognosis: The patches of hypopigmented skin are typically stable and do not change over time.

Option A. Vitiligo: This condition causes depigmented patches but is usually not associated with a white forelock and can be more variable in distribution.VItiligo develops later after birth.

Option B. Albinism: This condition leads to a generalized lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes, but does not typically feature localized patches or a white forelock.

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: This is associated with various skin manifestations, including hypopigmented macules, but does not have the specific presentation of piebaldism.

Key Takeaway:

  • Piebaldism is an autosomal dominant condition
  • Stable, well-defined patches of depigmented skin-white forelock since birth.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image showing a person with a significant lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes.
questions.solution:
Albinism is a genetic condition that results in a complete or partial absence of melanin, a pigment that gives skin, hair, and eyes their color. Individuals with albinism typically have very light skin and hair, often described as white or pale.

Key features of albinism:

  • Lack of melanin: This causes the skin, hair, and eyes to be lighter in color than usual.
  • Vision problems: People with albinism often have vision problems, such as poor eyesight, light sensitivity, and nystagmus (involuntary eye movements).
  • Genetic inheritance: Albinism is an inherited condition that can be passed down from parents to their children in Autosomal Recessive manner.

Option A. Vitiligo: This condition involves the loss of skin pigmentation in patches, but it does not affect the entire body uniformly as seen in albinism.

Option C. Piebaldism: This is a genetic condition that presents with white patches of skin and hair, but it usually involves some areas of normal pigmentation and does not affect the eyes.

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: This is a genetic disorder that causes benign tumors in multiple organs and may lead to skin findings such as hypopigmented macules, but it does not result in the generalized lack of pigmentation seen in albinism.

Key Takeaway

Albinism is a genetic condition marked by a complete or partial absence of melanin, resulting in a significant lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes, often accompanied by vision problems.

questions.text: A 6 year old male patient presented with small hypopigmented macules on cheek. There was xerosis over my face. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Pityriasis Alba

  • Type of dermatitis: A type of skin condition, specifically a form of eczema.
  • Age group: Predominantly affects children between 3 and 16 years old.
  • Gender: Affects both sexes equally.
  • Clinical features:
    • Lesions are typically rounded, oval, or irregularly shaped plaques.
    • Lesions may be red, pink, or skin-colored.
    • Fine, lamellar, or branny scaling is present.
    • Persistent fine scaling often leads to hypopigmentation (pale patches).
  • History: Often associated with a history of atopy (allergic tendencies).
  • Sensation: Sensation is typically intact, meaning there's no significant pain or itching.

Option A: P. Rosea

  • Reactive condition
  • Herald patch
  • Collarette scaling
  • Fir tree pattern of back
  • Recurrent in crops

Option B: P. Versicolor

  • Superficial fungal infection
  • Scaly macule show both hyper- and hypo- pigmentation
  • Seen on upper trunk and shoulders

Option C: Leprosy

  • Epidermal atrophy, wrinkling
  • Slight erythema or hypo pigmentation
  • Hypoesthesia

Key Takeaway

Pityriasis alba is the most likely diagnosis, characterized by small hypopigmented macules on the face, often seen in children with a history of atopy and associated with xerosis. The lesions are typically rounded or oval and may show fine scaling.

questions.text: What is the long term complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Congenital Melanocytic Nevi:
    • The image likely shows a hyperpigmented patch with increased hair growth, consistent with congenital melanocytic nevi. When these nevi exceed 20 cm in size, they are termed giant melanocytic nevi.
  • Long-Term Complication:
    • The primary long-term risk associated with congenital melanocytic nevi, especially giant ones, is the potential for malignant transformation into melanoma. This risk necessitates careful monitoring of the nevus for any changes in size, shape, color, or texture.

Rule of ABCDE for Melanoma:

  • A - Asymmetry: One half does not match the other.
  • B - Borders: Irregular or poorly defined edges.
  • C - Color: Varied colors within the mole.
  • D - Diameter: Larger than 6 mm.
  • E - Evolution: Any change in the nevus over time.

Option B, C & D: Other options like B. Cataract, C. Loss of vision, and D. Glaucoma are not directly associated with congenital melanocytic nevi and pertain more to ocular health rather than skin lesions.

Key Takeaway

The long-term complication of congenital melanocytic nevi, particularly giant nevi, is the potential for malignant transformation into melanoma. Careful monitoring for changes in size, shape, color, or texture is essential to detect any signs of malignancy early.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Segmental vitiligo is a type of vitiligo characterized by well-defined, hypopigmented (pale) patches of skin that are typically located on one side of the body and do not cross the midline.

Key characteristics of segmental vitiligo:

  • Age of onset: Often presents in childhood or adolescence.
  • Distribution: Patches are usually confined to one side of the body, following a dermatomal pattern.
  • Stability: Segmental vitiligo tends to be more stable than non-segmental vitiligo and may not progress significantly over time.
  • Treatment response: It can be less responsive to medical treatments compared to non-segmental vitiligo.

Option B: Hypomelanosis of Ito presents as linear white streaks in a Blaschkoid pattern and is often present from birth.

Option C: Nevus of Ito consists of blue-colored macules located in the acromioclavicular area.

Option D: Becker's nevus usually appears around puberty as dark brown macules with associated hypertrichosis.

Key Takeaway

Segmental vitiligo is characterized by well-defined hypopigmented patches that typically do not cross the midline of the body, often appearing in children. This condition is generally stable and less responsive to treatment,

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with depigmented patches over feet as shown in the image. Which chemical is responsible for it?
questions.solution:
Rubber can indeed cause allergic contact dermatitis, and one of the allergens commonly found in rubber is monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH).

Therefore, the correct answer is:

  • Rubber: Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH)

Other potential allergens and their associated items:

  • Bindi: Para-tertiary butyl phenol (PTBP) - Option B
  • Hair dye: Paraphenylenediamine (PPD) - Option A
  • Alloy: Nickel
  • Cement: Potassium dichromate - Option D

Key Takeaways:

  • MBEH is associated with contact leukoderma due to exposure to rubber materials.
  • Identifying the chemical cause is essential for management and prevention of further exposure and depigmentation.

questions.text: A female patient presented with skin lesions over the scalp,neck, ear and swelling of eyelids. She is a regular user of hair dye. Which chemical causes following allergic reaction?
questions.solution:
• Paraphenylenediamine (PPD) is a common allergen found in hair dyes and is known to induce allergic contact dermatitis (ACD).
  • Symptoms can include skin lesions, erythema, and swelling, particularly in areas where the dye has been applied.

Option A. Pollen: Typically causes allergic rhinitis or hay fever, not skin lesions from hair dye.

Option C. Balsam of Peru: An allergen found in topical products but less commonly associated with hair dyes.

Option D. Hexamethylenetetramine: Used in some cosmetics and resins but not a common cause of allergic reactions in hair dye.


Key Takeaways:

PPD is the primary chemical responsible for allergic reactions in individuals using hair dyes.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image?
questions.solution:
Contact leukoderma can occur over chronic exposure of chemicals. It's type 4 Hypersensitivity reaction.

  • Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is classified as Type 4 hypersensitivity, which is mediated by T cells rather than antibodies.
  • Mechanism:
    • The first exposure to an allergen leads to sensitization, primarily involving Langerhans cells that capture and present the allergen to T cells.
    • Upon re-exposure, T-memory cells are activated, leading to an inflammatory response.
  • Common Allergen:
  • Bindi: Para tertiary butyl phenol(PTBP)
  • Rubber: Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone(MBEH)
  • Hair dye: Paraphenylenediamine (PPD)

Option A: Vitiligo:

  • Characterized by progressive depigmented patches.
  • Can affect any age group.

Option B: Piebaldism:

  • An autosomal dominant condition due to a KIT gene mutation.
  • Presents with white triangular or rhomboid patch of depigmentation in frontal, median scalp with white forelock of hair since birth.

Option C: Oculocutaneous Albinism:

  • A genetic disorder affecting melanin biosynthesis, leading to reduced pigmentation in skin, hair, and eyes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Contact leukoderma is a localized form of skin depigmentation due to chemical exposure.

questions.text: Allergic contact dermatitis is_
questions.solution:
• Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is classified as Type 4 hypersensitivity, which is mediated by T cells rather than antibodies.
  • Mechanism:
    • The first exposure to an allergen leads to sensitization, primarily involving Langerhans cells that capture and present the allergen to T cells.
    • Upon re-exposure, T-memory cells are activated, leading to an inflammatory response.

Key Points:

  • Type 4 hypersensitivity is delayed-type and typically manifests 24-48 hours after re-exposure to the allergen.
  • Common allergens include nickel, fragrances, and certain chemicals in cosmetics and topical medications.

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for airborne contact dermatitis?
questions.solution:
• Patch test is the gold standard test for diagnosis of Allergic contact dermatitis.
  • ACD is type 4 hypersensitivity.
  • Allergens are applied over the back of the patient. First reading is done after 48 hours. Next reading should be done at 96 hours. (Best reading at 96 hrs).
  • Phytophotodermatitis is an air borne contact dermatitis, most common cause of ACD in india. Cause is plant - parthenium hysterophorus (Congress grass)
  • Antigen is Sesquiterpene lactone
  • Sites involved are exposed area of body
  • Photopatch test is useful test in photoallergic dermatitis, here UVA is used

Option A:Serum IgE is minor criteria in diagnosis of Atopic dermatitis

Option B: Radioallergosorbent test measures specific IgE

Option D: Immunoturbidimetry used to estimate serum protein.

Key Takeaway:

The investigation of choice for airborne contact dermatitis is the patch test, which is the gold standard for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis (ACD). This test assesses delayed-type hypersensitivity (type 4) by applying allergens to the skin.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient presented with complaints of itching over face and scalp.There was a history of regular hair oil application. On examination there were yellowish greasy scales around the nose, behind ears and scalp.What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Seborrheic dermatitis is characterized by yellowish greasy scales and is commonly found on areas rich in sebaceous glands, such as the scalp, face, and behind the ears.
  • Causative Agent: The condition is associated with Malassezia (formerly Pityrosporum ovale), a yeast that thrives in oily environments. The application of hair oil can exacerbate the condition by providing an enriched medium for its growth.

Option A. Psoriasis:

  • Characteristics: Typically presents as well-defined, red plaques with silvery-white scales. Commonly affects the elbows, knees, and scalp.
  • Symptoms: May be itchy, but not greasy. Often associated with nail changes and joint symptoms.

Option C. Atopic dermatitis:

  • Characteristics: Often presents as dry, itchy, red patches, commonly in flexural areas (elbows, knees) and on the face in children. It may have a chronic relapsing course.
  • Symptoms: Associated with a personal or family history of allergies, asthma, or hay fever.

Option D. Ichthyosis:

  • Characteristics: Presents with dry, thickened, scaly skin. The scales are often non-greasy and can cover large areas of the body.
  • This condition is usually congenital or hereditary.

Key Takeaway:

Seborrheic dermatitis:

  • Symptoms include greasy scales, redness, and itching in seborrheic areas (Scalp, face, V area of neck)
  • Treatment options may include antifungal shampoos, topical corticosteroids, and lifestyle modifications.

questions.text: A 2 month old male patient presented with a yellowish skin lesion over face and scalp.What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Seborrheic dermatitis is a common skin condition that often affects infants, commonly known as cradle cap. It is characterized by yellowish, greasy scales on the scalp, but can also extend to other areas of the face and body.

Key characteristics of seborrheic dermatitis in infants:

  • Yellowish, greasy scales: The lesions often have a yellowish or reddish color and a greasy texture.
  • Scalp involvement: Most commonly affects the scalp, but can also spread to the eyebrows, ears, and other areas.
  • Mild itching: May cause mild itching or discomfort.
  • Self-limiting: Seborrheic dermatitis in infants is usually a self-limiting condition and often resolves on its own.
  • Option A: Impetigo:

    • Characteristics: A bacterial skin infection most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. There are two types:
  • Option C: Ichthyosis:
    • Characteristics: A group of skin disorders characterized by dry, scaly skin. In severe cases, it can present at birth with a collodion membrane.
    • Symptoms: Generally presents with more widespread scaling and dryness rather than localized greasy lesions. Family history is often present.
  • Option D: Atopic dermatitis:
    • Characteristics: A chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, red, and inflamed skin.
    • Symptoms: Typically present in flexural areas (elbows, knees) and can affect the face, but the lesions are not usually yellowish or greasy.
    • Hanifin and rajka criteria for diagnosis of atopic dermatitis:

Key Takeaway:

Seborrheic dermatitis, often called cradle cap in infants, is the most likely diagnosis for a 2-month-old with yellowish, greasy lesions on the face and scalp. It typically appears as yellowish scales and can extend beyond the scalp, distinguishing it from conditions like impetigo, ichthyosis, and atopic dermatitis, which present differently.

questions.text: Which criteria is used for atopic dermatitis?
questions.solution:
Hanifin and Rajka Criteria for Atopic Dermatitis

Major Criteria:

  • Pruritus
  • Early age of onset
  • Typical morphology and distribution: flexural lichenification and linearity in adults; facial and extensor involvement during infancy and childhood
  • Chronic or chronically relapsing dermatitis
  • Personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinoconjunctivitis, atopic dermatitis)

Minor Criteria:

  • Xerosis
  • Hand/foot non-specific dermatitis
  • Pityriasis alba
  • Nipple eczema
  • White dermographism
  • Subcapsular cataract
  • Increased serum IgE level
  • Immediate (i.e., type 1) skin response
  • Susceptibility to cutaneous infections (especially Staphylococcus aureus and Herpes simplex)

Option A: Bohan and peter criteria is used for dermatomyositis.

Option B: CASPAR criteria is used for psoriatic arthritis.

Option C: Rotterdam criteria is used for Polycystic ovarian disease.

questions.text: 11 year old boy came to OPD with itchy erythematous plaque over neck, both arm's cubital fossa and both popliteal fossa since 2 years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Atopic dermatitis is characterized by itchy, erythematous plaques, particularly in flexural areas (like the cubital and popliteal fossae). The chronicity and itchiness align with this diagnosis, making it the most likely option.

The Hanifin and Rajka criteria can be used to diagnose atopic dermatitis.

Hanifin and Rajka Criteria for Atopic Dermatitis

Major Criteria:

  • Pruritus
  • Early age of onset
  • Typical morphology and distribution: flexural lichenification and linearity in adults; facial and extensor involvement during infancy and childhood
  • Chronic or chronically relapsing dermatitis
  • Personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinoconjunctivitis, atopic dermatitis)

Minor Criteria:

  • Xerosis
  • Hand/foot non-specific dermatitis
  • Pityriasis alba
  • Nipple eczema
  • White dermographism
  • Subcapsular cataract
  • Increased serum IgE level
  • Immediate (i.e., type 1) skin response
  • Susceptibility to cutaneous infections (especially Staphylococcus aureus and Herpes simplex)

Option B. Psoriasis vulgaris:

  • Characteristics: Presents with well-defined, erythematous plaques covered by silvery scales. Typically affects extensor surfaces (elbows, knees) and the scalp.

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

  • Characteristics: Associated with gluten sensitivity, presenting as vesicular lesions, excoriations, and crusts, often located on extensor surfaces and buttocks.
  • More common in adults and characterized by grouped vesicles rather than plaques.

Option D. Pemphigus vegetans:

  • Characteristics: A rare variant of pemphigus characterized by erosions and vegetative lesions in flexural areas.
  • Not common in children

choices.text: Parthenium is most common plant responsible
It is responsible for Chronic actinic dermatitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Phytophotodermatitis?
questions.solution:
It is responsible for Chronic actinic dermatitis. This statement is not true. Chronic actinic dermatitis is a different condition characterized by photosensitivity to sunlight, often seen in elderly individuals with a history of sun exposure. Phytophotodermatitis involves a reaction to plant chemicals when exposed to sunlight, but it does not cause chronic actinic dermatitis.

Phytophotodermatitis is a skin condition that occurs when certain plant substances, called furocoumarins, interact with ultraviolet (UV) light. This interaction causes a skin reaction that resembles dermatitis.

Key Points:

  • Cause: Exposure to furocoumarins in plants combined with exposure to sunlight.
  • Common culprit: Parthenium hysterophorus, a plant commonly found in India, is a frequent cause of phytophotodermatitis.
  • Type of reaction: Phytophotodermatitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction, a delayed-type allergic reaction.
  • Other plant substances: Sesquiterpene lactones found in certain plants can also trigger allergic reactions.

Option A. Parthenium is the most common plant responsible:

  • This statement is true. Parthenium hysterophorus is a common cause of phytophotodermatitis, especially in India.

Option B. Sesquiterpene lactone is an allergen:

  • This is also true. Sesquiterpene lactones found in certain plants can trigger allergic reactions.

Option D. It is Type 4 hypersensitivity:

  • This statement is true. Phytophotodermatitis is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type 4 hypersensitivity).

Key Takeaway:

  • Phytophotodermatitis is a skin condition caused by the interaction of certain plant substances (furocoumarins) with ultraviolet (UV) light, leading to dermatitis.
  • Parthenium hysterophorus is a common cause of phytophotodermatitis, especially in India.
  • Phytophotodermatitis is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type 4 hypersensitivity).
  • Sesquiterpene lactones found in certain plants can trigger allergic reactions.

questions.text: A 20 year old female presented with intense itching over both palms with sago grain like appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pompholyx, also known as dyshidrotic eczema, is a skin condition characterized by the appearance of small, itchy vesicles on the palms and sides of the fingers. These vesicles often resemble sago grains or tapioca pearls.

Key features of pompholyx:

  • Vesicular lesions: Small, fluid-filled blisters on the palms and sides of the fingers.
  • Intense itching: Often accompanied by severe itching.
  • Association with stress or atopy: May be linked to emotional stress or a history of atopic dermatitis.

Treatment for pompholyx typically involves topical corticosteroids or emollients to help relieve itching and promote healing. In severe cases, systemic corticosteroids or light therapy may be considered.

Option B. Irritant contact dermatitis:

  • This condition typically causes redness, swelling, and irritation due to direct contact with irritants.

Option C. Scald:

  • Scalding refers to skin damage caused by hot liquids, leading to burns rather than vesicular lesions with intense itching.

Option D. Asteatotic eczema:

  • This condition presents with dry, cracked, and itchy skin, It is more common in older adults.

Key takeaway:

  • Pompholyx (dyshidrotic eczema), presents as small, vesicular lesions on the palms and sides of the fingers, giving a "sago grain" or "tapioca" appearance.
  • It is often associated with intense itching

questions.text: A 20 year old male patient presented with fluid filled itchy lesions with erythema around the ear for 1 day. A day before, he underwent a minor dermatological facial procedure. The face and surrounding area was cleaned with povidone iodine. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Irritant contact dermatitis is a skin condition caused by direct contact with an irritating substance, such as povidone iodine. It can occur in anyone who is exposed to the irritant, regardless of their skin sensitivity.

Key features of irritant contact dermatitis:

  • Immediate onset: Symptoms often appear shortly after exposure to the irritant.
  • Restricted to areas of contact: The rash is typically confined to the areas of the skin that came into contact with the irritant.
  • Symptoms: Itching, burning, redness, and the development of vesicles (small, fluid-filled blisters).
  • Severity: The severity of the reaction can depend on the nature of the irritant, the duration of exposure, and the individual's skin sensitivity.

Option A. Insect bite hypersensitivity:

  • This would typically present with localized swelling, redness, and itching at the site of the bite,

Option B. Allergic contact dermatitis:

  • This is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction that would take longer than one day to develop after exposure to an allergen. It typically causes pruritic, erythematous lesions, but the rapid onset here makes this less likely.

Option D. Bacterial infection:

  • While a bacterial infection could cause fluid-filled lesions, it would typically present with additional signs such as fever or systemic symptoms.

Key takeaway:

  • Irritant contact dermatitis can occur immediately after exposure and affects only the areas that came into contact with the irritant, such as povidone iodine.
  • It can occur in everyone who is exposed.
